I know, the most dreaded topic no one wants to think about. You see these advertisements for different medications and they all have the same warning about not taking if you have an infection, all well and good except what if you have been taking one or more of these for six months or a year and your cells and organs are saturated with it and then you come into contact with something like a virulent pathogen (and if they are taking one or more they probably have one or more underlying conditions in addition to a now diminished immune response).
A perfect storm, couple that with vitamin and mineral deficiencies, and a virus that can go with little harm to some can cause great harm to others.

We should also take a look and see how much of the virus is able to take refuge in the red blood cells of people that have gotten over the virus. If there is no further risk of transmission, universal donors (especially in certain cases where blood type may be a contributing factor) and the fact that so many people of different blood types have gotten over the virus, whole blood may offer an additional solution. We are going  to have to come at this from as many different angles as we can think of, not just one or snother. Whole blood also has nutrients that the cells and organs can readily absorb.

In some of the plasma treatments the concentration of antibodies is not high enough. A crucial step is being skipped. It work better if you allow the antibodies to grow and multiply in an incubator before administering them.

The problem isn't effectiveness.
We have known that it works well for over 60 years. The problem is perspective. Antibodies can not be patented and there is little money to be made from a Pharmaceutical sales perspective so nobody lobbies for it, in turn very little money is spent on development (also it would be their direct competition). So we have a perfectly good natural (produced by the human body no less) cure for many illnesses that we are not only failing to take advantage of, but we are poisoning ourselves trying to get around it!
Chemical compounds do not belong in the human body and are problematic. Human Antibodies do and work better than any other solution, but they can't make money from it so we can't have it!

Here's my question, and it's almost not facetious.  Is there anything we DO know?  After 6 months of frantic study of this surreal puzzle of a disease, are we sure of anything?  Kids usually don't get sick (except when they die or almost die), but even when asymptomatic, they have a larger viral load than adults.  WHY?  People may be able to get reinfected, and there's no good evidence of how long immunity lasts (if it exists at all), yet we're staking our social and economic futures on a vaccine.  WHY?  The virus apparently can pass the blood-brain barrier via some bulb or another, but it usually doesn't.  WHY?  The virus can attack seemingly almost any organ in the body, yet some people don't get sick at all, and there''s no pattern as to who does and who doesn't.  WHY?  The most severe cases seem to be caused by the body's own immune response, yet some people don't have an immune response at all, and there's no pattern as to who does and who doesn't.  WHY?  After over a hundred years of experience with the germ theory of disease and victories over a huge range of once-deadly infections, human society has been brought to its knees by something a pangolin caught from a bat and passed to a human in a wet market -- or something created experimentally in a Chinese lab that got loose by accident -- or that didn't come from China at all.  How can anything so seemingly simple as a spiky little blob of DNA cause such an endless variety of suffering?  We are Jon Snow.  We know nothing.

Hank is absolutely right that T cell immunity only refers to T cells activating and exerting an immune response to the coronavirus. This doesn’t necessarily imply that people are immune to it though. If that was the case, authors of these studies would use the term “T cell-mediated protection” or something to that effect. A vaccine will need to elicit a protective immune response for it to be effective. It’s useful to know that T cells react to coronavirus, even in people who haven’t been exposed to it, but until we have clinical data we won’t know if this response is protective or not.
